results_summary: The study found that low-density DQ nanocarriers (Q-LipoDQ LD) effectively minimized oxidative stress in TM4 cells, while high-density DQ (Q-LipoDQ HD) did not. The physical characteristics and encapsulation efficiency were not significantly affected by DQ density, but zeta potential decreased with lower DQ density.
population_specificity: TM4 cells (a mouse Sertoli cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Quercetin, co-delivered with PARP-1 siRNA via hybrid micelles (Q/siP-c-M), to prevent cataract development by regulating inflammatory conditions and immune responses.
results_summary: Q/siP-c-M improved transcorneal delivery of Quercetin and siRNA, increased catalase activity and ATP content, reduced PARP-1 protein expression, and prevented lipid peroxidation in the lens. Quercetin also decreased neutrophil extracellular trap formation and downregulated pro-inflammatory cytokines, suggesting therapeutic potential for excessive inflammatory reactions in the eyes.
population_specificity: Selenite-induced cataract rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quercetin could delay gefitinib-induced cardiomyocyte apoptosis in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and explore its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: Quercetin inhibited gefitinib-induced ventricular fibrosis, activated SHP2 protein expression, downregulated XBP-1 and p-STING expression, reduced ROS production, and promoted mitochondrial autophagy, thereby protecting against cardiomyocyte apoptosis.
population_specificity: Nude mice with NSCLC treated with gefitinib.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if quercetin could alleviate symptoms of skeletal fluorosis (SF) and Kashin-Beck disease (KBD) by targeting the HIF-1 signaling and ferroptosis pathways.
results_summary: The study identified quercetin as the best candidate therapeutic drug for SF and KBD through bioinformatics, molecular docking, and molecular dynamics simulations, suggesting it may regulate the HIF-1 and ferroptosis pathways to treat both diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on bioinformatics and molecular simulations).

study_goal: The study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of topical compound heparin sodium allantoin gel for treating papulopustular rosacea, not Quercetin.
results_summary: The study found that compound heparin sodium allantoin gel improved facial erythema, reduced itching and burning, and enhanced skin barrier function compared to traditional therapy, but it did not evaluate Quercetin.
population_specificity: 82 patients with papulopustular rosacea.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study focused on topical gel application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Quercetin could mitigate DEHP-induced bursa of Fabricius pyroptosis and necroptosis in chickens and MSB-1 cells.
results_summary: Quercetin reduced necroptosis and pyroptosis, inhibited the MAPK/NF-κB pathway, and mitigated oxidative stress caused by DEHP. The effects were counteracted by reactive oxygen species and NF-κB activators.
population_specificity: Chickens and MSB-1 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of quercetin in preventing and treating mastitis by examining its anti-inflammatory and epigenetic effects in bovine mammary epithelial cells and murine models.
results_summary: Quercetin inhibited inflammatory responses, reduced morphological damage, disrupted S. aureus adhesion, and modulated CCL5 expression via m6A methylation. It also altered genes related to inflammation and tissue remodeling, demonstrating dual roles in inflammation suppression and epigenetic regulation.
population_specificity: Bovine mammary epithelial cells (BMECs) and murine models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Quercetin could reverse depression-like behaviors and restore hippocampal neurogenesis by regulating microglia-derived exosomes and the Wnt1/β-catenin signaling pathway.
results_summary: Quercetin improved depression-like behaviors and restored neurogenesis in the hippocampus by suppressing microglia-derived exosomes carrying let-7e-5p, which targets the Wnt1/β-catenin pathway. The study confirmed that Quercetin effectively reverses the inhibitory effects of let-7e-5p on neurogenesis.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS) to induce depressive-like behaviors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether quercetin could mitigate myocardial injury in diabetic rats by influencing cuproptosis signaling and restoring L-type calcium channel activity.
results_summary: Quercetin improved cardiac function, reduced serum copper levels, downregulated FDX1 expression, and enhanced L-type calcium currents in diabetic rats. It also lowered CK-MB and LDH levels in high-glucose-exposed cardiomyocytes, though its effects were less pronounced when combined with elesclomol.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic Sprague-Dawley rats and cultured rat cardiomyocyte H9c2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which quercetin improves cardiac function, inflammation, and fibrosis in autoimmune myocarditis, focusing on the ERK1/2-C/EBPβ axis.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly improved cardiac function, reduced inflammation and fibrosis in mice with experimental autoimmune myocarditis (EAM), and down-regulated MCP-1 expression via the ERK1/2-C/EBPβ pathway. The effect was enhanced by the ERK1/2 inhibitor PD98059.
population_specificity: Mice with experimental autoimmune myocarditis (EAM) and H9C2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the anti-inflammatory effects of quercetin and its derivatives in in vivo models of neuroinflammation induced by lipopolysaccharide.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) and microgliosis in animal models, with antioxidant and anti-apoptotic properties mediated via Nrf2/HO-1 and caspase pathways. However, methodological quality and risk of bias were noted as limitations.
population_specificity: In vivo animal models (neuroinflammatory insults induced by lipopolysaccharide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-virulence effect of nano-quercetin-mediated photodynamic therapy on biofilm formation and gene expression in Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans.
results_summary: PDT with nano-quercetin significantly reduced bacterial count, metabolic activity, and expression of biofilm-related genes (rcpA, qseB, qseC) while increasing reactive oxygen species production. The highest metabolic activity reduction (42.9%) occurred at 8 µg/mL N-QT with 5-min irradiation.
population_specificity: In vitro study on Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, a periodontopathogen.
effective_dosage: 2–512 µg/mL N-QT, with irradiation durations of 4–6 min at energy densities of 103.9–154.8 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if encapsulating quercetin in PLGA nanoparticles could enhance its therapeutic potential against non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
results_summary: Nano-PLGA encapsulated quercetin (NPEQ) induced apoptosis and inhibited proliferation in K-ras mutated NSCLC cells, downregulated Akt, and reduced tumor volume in mice. NPEQ showed cytotoxic effects at doses of 347-406 ng/ml in vitro.
population_specificity: K-ras mutated NSCLC cells (A549 and H460) and tumor-bearing mice.
effective_dosage: 406 ng/ml for A549 cells, 347 ng/ml for H460 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-tumor effects of quercetin on A375 melanoma cells via GPER activation and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Quercetin inhibited proliferation and migration, induced apoptosis, and blocked the cell cycle at S and G2/M phases in A375 cells. It enhanced GPER-mediated signaling, evidenced by increased P-ERK and c-Myc expression, an effect blocked by the GPER antagonist G15.
population_specificity: A375 cutaneous melanoma cell line
effective_dosage: Up to 100 µM (concentrations tested, but exact dosage frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of quercetin-loaded nanophytosome (QNP) in modulating oxido-inflammatory responses in a rat model of early life stress induced by maternal isolation.
results_summary: QNP (40 mg/kg) significantly improved cognitive function, increased hippocampal dopamine levels, reduced oxidative stress, and decreased TNF-α and IL-6 expression in rats subjected to early life stress.
population_specificity: Male rat pups subjected to maternal isolation as a model of early life stress.
effective_dosage: 10 and 40 mg/kg of quercetin and QNP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate quercetin's protective effects against arsenic-induced oxidative damage, inflammation, and apoptosis in mouse BALB/c 3T3 fibroblast cells.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in arsenic-exposed cells, demonstrating anti-apoptotic and anti-inflammatory effects. Molecular docking studies showed strong binding affinity with key proteins involved in these processes.
population_specificity: Mouse BALB/c 3T3 fibroblast cells (NIH-3T3)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of quercetin-based nanoformulations for treating Human Metapneumovirus (hMPV) infections by enhancing bioavailability and antiviral efficacy.
results_summary: Quercetin-loaded nanoparticles demonstrated strong antiviral effects by inhibiting hMPV replication and reducing inflammatory markers in vitro and in vivo. The nanoformulations improved solubility and bioavailability, enhancing quercetin's therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Primarily studied in the context of hMPV infections, which affect children, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coordinating manganese ions with quercetin in a nano-activator could enhance cGAS-STING pathway activation and antitumor immune responses.
results_summary: The nano-activator demonstrated superior tumor-targeting, efficient cellular internalization, and induced immunogenic cell death, significantly enhancing antitumor immune responses when combined with anti-CTLA-4 antibodies.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prophylactic, antiviral, and therapeutic potential of quercetin against dengue virus (DENV) in infected mice, assessing its effects via pre-treatment, co-treatment, and post-treatment administration.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced DENV copy numbers, pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6), ROS production, and vascular leakage, with intraperitoneal administration showing greater efficacy than oral. Molecular docking indicated quercetin's strong interaction with viral proteins, suggesting antiviral and anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: DENV-infected Balb/C mice
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (assessed at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-infection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve quercetin's bioavailability and antitumor efficacy by developing cRGD-modified dextran-quercetin polymer micelles (R-D-Q) for targeted drug delivery in tumor therapy.
results_summary: R-D-Q micelles demonstrated higher cytotoxicity, apoptosis induction, and tumor penetration in MCF-7 cells compared to unmodified micelles, effectively suppressing tumor growth in mice by activating p38/JNK pathways and inhibiting ERK signaling, with no observed damage to normal tissues.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer MCF-7 cells and tumor-bearing mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Quercetin-Magnesium nanoparticles (Que-Mg2+ NPs) encapsulated in sodium alginate microspheres (Que-Mg@SA) for treating osteoarthritis by assessing their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and cartilage-protective effects.
results_summary: The study found that Que-Mg@SA microspheres effectively restored chondrocyte viability, scavenged ROS, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and balanced cartilage metabolism in an H2O2-induced OA cell model. The nanoparticles demonstrated sustained drug release, high stability, and biocompatibility.
population_specificity: H2O2-induced osteoarthritis cell model (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an efficient drug delivery system for Quercetin (Que) to enhance its bioavailability and therapeutic efficacy in pancreatic cancer by encapsulating it in liposomes conjugated with hyaluronidase (HAase).
results_summary: The study found that HQL (HAase-conjugated Que liposomes) effectively degraded hyaluronic acid in the tumor microenvironment, enhancing nanoparticle penetration and significantly inhibiting tumor growth in mice. HQL also demonstrated strong anti-proliferative, pro-apoptotic, and cell cycle arrest effects in pancreatic cancer models, downregulating key proteins involved in cell cycle and apoptosis pathways.
population_specificity: Xenografted tumor mice and pancreatic cancer cell lines, including 3D cultured cell spheroids and PDAC-derived organoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how quercetin (QUR) and/or mexamine (MEX) prevented synfat-induced brain damage in rat models, focusing on inflammatory pathways, DNA damage, and Fischer's ratio.
results_summary: QUR and MEX therapy improved hemoglobin levels, reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory biomarkers, and mitigated synfat-induced DNA damage, suggesting a protective effect against hypoxemia-related brain injury.
population_specificity: Rat models with synfat-induced hypoxemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the remineralization effect of quercetin nanoparticles (QNPs) on artificial white spot lesions compared to fluoride and quercetin microparticles.
results_summary: QNPs showed similar remineralization potential to fluoride and were more effective than quercetin microparticles, with significant improvements in surface microhardness and Ca:P ratios. No significant differences were found between QNPs and fluoride in any test.
population_specificity: Extracted human molars (n=76) with artificial white spot lesions.
effective_dosage: 4000 ppm QNPs, 6.5% w/v quercetin microparticles, 1000 ppm fluoride solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how Quercetin suppresses neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in ulcerative colitis (UC) and activates the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (Ahr) in neutrophils.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly improved gut barrier function in a DSS-induced colitis model by inhibiting the NF-κB pathway, upregulating Ahr/Arnt and Nqo1, and reducing NET formation. It also activated Ahr translocation and reduced ROS production in neutrophils.
population_specificity: DSS-induced ulcerative colitis model in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of quercetin in managing late-onset hypogonadism (LOH) by enhancing testosterone synthesis and reducing testicular aging.
results_summary: Quercetin improved sperm velocity, increased testosterone levels in serum and testicular tissue, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and modulated the AR/PI3K/AKT pathway to enhance testosterone synthesis and reduce aging markers in testicular Leydig cells.
population_specificity: Aging murine model (mice) and aged TM3 testicular Leydig cells.
study_duration: Treatment started at 12 weeks of age (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective potential of Quercetin-derived carbon dots (QCDs) on Schwann cell proliferation, migration, and neurite outgrowth in vitro.
results_summary: QCDs demonstrated significant free radical scavenging activity, supported Schwann cell proliferation and migration, enhanced neurotrophic and angiogenic growth factor expression, and stimulated neurite outgrowth in NG108-15 cells.
population_specificity: Cultured Schwann cells and NG108-15 cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of quercetin and its derivatives in mitigating chemotherapy-induced cognitive impairment (chemobrain) by targeting the NAMPT and SIRT1 pathways.
results_summary: Quercetin and its derivatives (rutin and isoquercetin) showed protective effects against chemotherapy-induced toxicity in SH-SY5Y cells, enhancing NAMPT and SIRT1 gene expression and shielding cells from oxidative damage. The phytochemicals demonstrated potential in alleviating cognitive impairment linked to chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Differentiated SH-SY5Y cell lines (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Quercetin (0.12, 0.6 µM), rutin, and isoquercetin (16, 80 µM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop quercetin-incorporated squalene nanostructured lipid carriers (QS-NLCs) to improve the treatment of dry eye disease (DED) by enhancing quercetin's bioavailability and pharmacological effects.
results_summary: QS-NLCs demonstrated high drug loading, stability, sustained release, and improved corneal permeation compared to free quercetin. They also showed significant anti-inflammatory and cytotoxicity activities, enhanced tear production, and higher bioavailability with good ocular tolerance.
population_specificity: The study used RAW 264.7 and HCECs cell lines for in vitro testing, and the modified Draize test for ocular tolerance.
study_duration: 5-day tear production study; stability tested for 90 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether quercetin, as part of a nanoemulsion, could enhance the differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells into neural cells.
results_summary: Quercetin at 25 μg/ml, alongside Melissa officinalis extract and caffeic acid, increased the expression of neural marker genes and proteins in differentiated cells compared to controls, with statistically significant results (P ≤ 0.05).
population_specificity: Human Wharton's jelly-derived mesenchymal stem cells (WJ-MSCs) in a laboratory environment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily quercetin glucoside ingestion enhances muscle strength and motor unit adaptations in older adults undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Quercetin ingestion (200 mg/day) led to greater improvements in maximal voluntary force compared to placebo, with increased firing rates in motor units with higher recruitment thresholds, suggesting enhanced neuromuscular adaptations. Muscle mass remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic cardioprotective effects of nano-quercetin (N-QCT) and curcumin on human vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), focusing on the TGF-β signaling pathway.
results_summary: The combination of N-QCT and curcumin significantly enhanced Nrf2 protein expression, upregulated antioxidant enzymes, reduced ROS production, and modulated Erk1/2 phosphorylation, demonstrating pronounced cardioprotective effects. These effects were achieved through inhibition of ROS/Erk1/2 signaling and activation of Nrf2 and antioxidant enzymes.
population_specificity: Human vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), including TGF-β-stimulated VSMCs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if loading Quercetin onto a magnetic iron oxide nanoparticle carrier (MAG@PEG@QUE) could enhance its bioavailability and targeted delivery for breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: MAG@PEG@QUE significantly reduced cell proliferation and viability while increasing apoptosis in MCF-7 cells, showing comparable antitumor effects to free Quercetin. Targeted delivery using a static magnetic field led to high intracellular accumulation and selective cell death without affecting adjacent cells.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Concentration equivalent to the IC50 of free Quercetin (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Quercetin (QR), a core component of Tangliping Decoction (TLP), improves diabetic cognitive impairment (DCI) by modulating gut microbiota and restoring gut and brain barrier integrity.
results_summary: Quercetin improved learning and memory in DCI mice, reduced insulin resistance, restored β-cell function, and modulated gut microbiota composition. Fecal microbiota transplantation from QR-treated mice improved cognitive function and gut barrier integrity in pseudo-sterile DCI mice.
population_specificity: Diabetic cognitive impairment (DCI) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Quercetin mitigates DEHP-induced duodenal pyroptosis and programmed necrosis in broiler chickens via the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: Quercetin reduced oxidative stress, inhibited the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway, and alleviated DEHP-induced pyroptosis and programmed necrosis in chicken duodenum. In vitro experiments confirmed that reactivating NF-κB signaling reversed Quercetin's protective effects.
population_specificity: Broiler chickens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of quercetin on colorectal cancer (CRC) treatment and progression, particularly its potential in combination with conventional therapies.
results_summary: Quercetin inhibited cancer progression through cell cycle arrest and apoptosis induction, sensitized cancer cells to chemotherapy, and showed protective effects on normal cells. It also reduced tumor growth and modulated inflammatory and immune signaling pathways in CRC.
population_specificity: Animal and clinical studies related to colorectal cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dasatinib and quercetin (D + Q) treatment could mitigate age-related alveolar bone resorption by targeting senescent cells, SASP, and neutrophil infiltration.
results_summary: D + Q treatment improved alveolar bone health by reducing bone resorption, enhancing periodontal ligament thickness, and balancing osteometabolism. It also decreased senescent cell accumulation, SASP expression, and neutrophil infiltration in aged mice.
population_specificity: Aged C57BL/6 mice (18 months old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dual sustained-release hydrogel-ZIF-8 system containing Quercetin could optimize local immune responses and promote osteogenic differentiation by regulating inflammatory factors.
results_summary: The study found that the Quercetin-loaded system produced early-stage mild anti-inflammatory effects and later-stage enhanced anti-inflammatory responses, reconfiguring the local microenvironment and promoting osteogenic differentiation by inhibiting the NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: In vivo and in vitro models (specific human or animal population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors affecting quercetin bioavailability in humans from different formulations and food matrices.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin bioavailability was significantly influenced by chemical structure (e.g., quercetin-3-O-oligoglucosides showed higher bioavailability), physicochemical modifications (e.g., cyclodextrin inclusion complex increased bioavailability 10.8-fold), and food matrix effects (e.g., dietary fats and fiber doubled bioavailability).
population_specificity: Human intervention studies (specific population not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and evaluate the protective effects and potential mechanisms of quercetin in pulmonary fibrosis (PF) animal models.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced lung pathological tissue scores, fibrosis markers, inflammatory responses, oxidative stress, and other fibrotic processes in PF models without significant hepatic or nephrotoxicity. A dosing period over 20 days and dosages of 5-100 mg/kg were identified as effective.
population_specificity: Animal models of pulmonary fibrosis (1019 animals across 20 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quercetin-ethylenediamine carbon quantum dots (QECQDs) could mitigate oxidative stress and iron overload following intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) to improve neurological outcomes.
results_summary: QECQDs effectively scavenged free radicals, protected cells from oxidative stress, improved cerebral blood flow, reduced hemorrhage volume, alleviated edema, and enhanced neurological function in ICH models.
population_specificity: In vitro (HT22 cells) and in vivo (animal models of ICH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential molecular targets of quercetin in the treatment of clear cell renal carcinoma (ccRCC) and evaluate its therapeutic effects.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly inhibited cell proliferation and migration in ccRCC cells and suppressed TP53 expression at mRNA and protein levels. TP53, ARF4, and DPP4 were identified as core targets mediating quercetin's therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Cultured 786-O cells (a clear cell renal carcinoma cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess quercetin's ability to protect the heart from tacrolimus-induced cardiotoxicity.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced elevated cardiac and inflammatory biomarkers, lowered oxidative stress markers (MDA), and increased antioxidant levels (GSH, SOD, GR, CAT). It also mitigated histological damage in cardiac tissue, such as vacuole formation and hypertrophy.
population_specificity: 30 rats divided into 5 groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quercetin could mitigate HIV-1 gp120-induced astrocyte neurotoxicity and cognitive impairment by reducing oxidative stress and promoting stress granule disassembly.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced oxidative stress and stress granule formation in astrocytes, improved cognitive function in transgenic mice, and upregulated proteins associated with stress granule depolymerization.
population_specificity: Primary rat astrocytes and HIV-1 gp120 transgenic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Quercetin's protective roles in mitigating necroptosis and apoptosis triggered by LPS-induced mitochondrial and metabolic imbalances in broiler livers, focusing on m6A methylation modulation.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced METTL3 expression, decreased PTEN m6A methylation, and suppressed factors related to mitochondrial fission, necroptosis, and apoptosis. It also promoted mitochondrial fusion, energy metabolism, anti-apoptosis, and PI3K/AKT signaling, while increasing ΔΨm, ATP content, and ATPase activity.
population_specificity: Broiler livers (in vivo and in vitro LMH cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate quercetin's potential therapeutic effects on psoriasis and its relationship with the PI3K/AKT/GLUT1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Quercetin reduced psoriasis-like skin lesions in mice, suppressed HaCaT cell proliferation, promoted apoptosis, and modulated the PI3K/AKT/GLUT1 pathway.
population_specificity: Imiquimod-induced psoriasis mouse model and HaCaT human keratinocyte cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Quercetin could alleviate cadmium-induced kidney damage in rats and explore its mechanism via the IRE1α-XBP1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Quercetin reduced cadmium-induced kidney tissue damage and cell apoptosis by inhibiting the IRE1α-XBP1 signaling pathway, as evidenced by decreased mRNA and protein expression levels.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the anti-cancer potential of quercetin against oral cancer cells by reviewing existing studies.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced cancer cell proliferation, viability, tumor volume, invasion, metastasis, and migration, while inducing oxidative stress and apoptosis. However, its clinical use is limited by poor absorption rates and unclear molecular mechanisms.
population_specificity: Oral cancer cells (in vitro/in vivo studies, not specified if human or animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quercetin, when delivered via PDMS-HA nanoparticles alongside doxorubicin, could enhance antitumor effects by overcoming multidrug resistance and promoting cytotoxicity in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Quercetin combined with doxorubicin significantly reduced tumor volume by 65% in a breast cancer xenograft model, enhanced intracellular drug accumulation, and induced apoptosis and cell cycle arrest without notable systemic toxicity. The PDMS-HA nanoparticle system improved targeted delivery and efficacy compared to single-drug or free-drug combinations.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells and NOD/SCID mice with xenograft tumors.
interactions: Synergistic interaction with doxorubicin noted for reversing multidrug resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a microemulsion system (ME-50) for enhancing the topical co-delivery and antioxidant effects of quercetin and α-lipoic acid in skin tissue.
results_summary: The study found that ME-50 significantly improved quercetin accumulation in the stratum corneum (2.4-fold) and delivery to viable epidermis and dermis (3.5-fold) compared to control solutions. The co-loaded ME also enhanced antioxidant activity in skin layers and reduced oxidative species in keratinocytes by 55%.
population_specificity: In vitro (keratinocytes) and ex vivo (skin penetration studies) models.
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentration in ME-50 not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of quercetin on a mouse model of endometriosis and elucidate its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Quercetin reduced ectopic lesion weights, increased PPARγ expression, and decreased protein expression levels of MAT2A, PRMT5, SAM, cyclin D1, and C-MYC, while also reducing vimentin, Ki67, VEGF, and caspase-1 expressions. These changes suggest quercetin modulates gene transcription and inhibits ectopic endometrial cell growth.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with induced endometriosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of quercetin on mast cell responsiveness, focusing on its dual role in inhibiting and sensitizing mast cells, to optimize its therapeutic use in chronic inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: Short-term quercetin treatment reduced mast cell activity, but prolonged exposure transiently enhanced both IgE-mediated and non-IgE-mediated responses, downregulating IgE-mediated degranulation while potentially sensitizing cells to other secretagogues via enhanced PKC activity.
population_specificity: Rat basophilic leukemia (RBL-2H3) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of quercetin on lowering uric acid levels and improving kidney and liver function in animal models of hyperuricemia.
results_summary: Quercetin effectively reduced uric acid levels, improved kidney and liver function, and modulated oxidative stress, lipid metabolism, and transporter proteins. It showed significant effects in lowering serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels compared to the positive control group.
population_specificity: Animal models of hyperuricemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypouricemic effect and safety of Quercetin Phytosome™ (QP) supplementation in healthy and metabolically compromised adults.
results_summary: QP significantly reduced serum uric acid levels (13.1%-15.2%) and triglycerides (10.2%-20.8%) in hyperuricemic and metabolically compromised individuals, with high tolerability and minimal side effects.
population_specificity: Healthy adults, mildly hyperuricemic adults with metabolic disorders, and obese adults with hypercholesterolemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quercetin could alleviate LPS/iE-DAP-induced ferroptosis and liver injury by targeting the IL-6/STAT3 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Quercetin pretreatment reduced hepatic iron accumulation and mitigated LPS/iE-DAP-induced ferroptosis and liver injury by inhibiting the IL-6/STAT3 pathway, effects reversed by recombinant bovine IL-6.
population_specificity: Bovine hepatocytes and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how quercetin affects apoptosis and autophagy in pediatric AML cells by regulating the miR-224-3p/PTEN axis and inhibiting the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.
results_summary: Quercetin increased apoptosis and reduced autophagy in AML cells by downregulating miR-224-3p and upregulating PTEN, thereby inhibiting the PI3K/AKT pathway. These effects were reversed when miR-224-3p was upregulated or PTEN was downregulated.
population_specificity: Pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients and healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Quercetin alleviates SiO2-induced ferroptosis via ROS/PPARγ, thereby restoring testicular angiogenesis in mice.
results_summary: Quercetin treatment alleviated SiO2-induced antioxidant dysfunction, upregulated PPARγ, reduced ferroptosis, and restored angiogenesis. The effects of Quercetin were diminished by oxidative stress activators, PPARγ inhibitors, and ferroptosis activators.
population_specificity: Mice and C166 cell models exposed to SiO2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of one-week quercetin ingestion on motor unit behavior and muscle contractile properties during resistance exercise in older adults.
results_summary: Quercetin reduced motor unit recruitment threshold and increased normalized force per firing rate, suggesting improved neuromuscular efficiency, but also led to greater fatigue in higher-threshold motor units during resistance exercise. No significant differences were observed in electrically elicited contractions between quercetin and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential preventive value and mechanism of Quercitrin (Que) against myocardial infarction (MI) by examining its effects on cardiac remodeling and macrophage polarization.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with Que improved cardiac function (fractional shortening, ejection fraction), reduced infarct size, attenuated cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis, and modulated macrophage polarization from M1-like to M2-like, leading to improved survival and reduced adverse ventricular remodeling post-MI.
population_specificity: Adult male C57BL/6 mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of quercetin (Que) in inhibiting platelet apoptosis and enhancing the tumor-targeting capabilities of an engineered platelet platform (PDQLs).
results_summary: Quercetin effectively inhibited platelet apoptosis by activating serine/threonine protein kinase, contributing to the stability and tumor-targeting ability of PDQLs. PDQLs showed improved storage stability and tumor accumulation, with a 10.63-fold increase in the area under the curve compared to the solution.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo study, likely animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 7-day quercetin glycoside ingestion alters motor unit recruitment thresholds and activation patterns before and after resistance exercise.
results_summary: Quercetin glycosides (200 mg/day) reduced motor unit recruitment thresholds more than placebo after 7 days, suggesting improved neuromuscular efficiency. The effect was observed in submaximal contractions of the vastus lateralis muscle.
population_specificity: Twenty young male and female adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether benesco™ (a quercetin-based supplement) could improve reflux symptoms in patients with GERD compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of quercetin over placebo in reducing reflux symptoms, with similar rates of treatment success, reflux-free days, and reflux-free nights between groups.
population_specificity: Participants with reflux symptoms (GERD patients).
effective_dosage: 200 mg of quercetin three times daily (600 mg total daily dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Quercetin on cardiometabolic factors by summarizing findings from meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: Quercetin supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure (SBP) and insulin levels but had no effect on diastolic blood pressure (DBP), lipid profile, inflammation, anthropometric indices, fasting plasma glucose (FBG), or insulin resistance (HOMA-IR).
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of multiple RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of quercetin supplementation on systolic and diastolic blood pressure in normotensive and (pre)hypertensive adults.
results_summary: Quercetin supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure in mixed and normotensive populations and diastolic blood pressure in (pre)hypertensive adults. The effects were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Normotensive and (pre)hypertensive adults (841 participants total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Quercetin's potential therapeutic and prophylactic efficacy against COVID-19 and its comorbidities based on preclinical and preliminary clinical evidence.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Quercetin may inhibit SARS-CoV-2 infection factors and mitigate COVID-19 symptoms in comorbid patients, but further high-power clinical trials are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19 and comorbidities like COPD, diabetes, obesity, coagulopathy, and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 4-week oral intake of quercetin could alleviate allergen-induced symptoms and improve quality of life in Japanese adults with pollinosis.
results_summary: The quercetin-containing supplement significantly improved allergic symptoms (eye itching, sneezing, nasal discharge, sleep disorder) and quality of life compared to placebo, with minor adverse effects noted.
population_specificity: Japanese adults (22-78 years old) with allergic symptoms of pollinosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of quercetin on diabetes mellitus and related metabolic disorders, focusing on its role in balancing antioxidant defense and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin positively impacts diabetes mellitus and related metabolic disorders by influencing the balance between antioxidant defense and oxidative stress. Multiple studies support these beneficial effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general reference to diabetes mellitus and metabolic disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of quercetin on circulating levels of IGF-I and IGF-II, as well as its impact on muscle damage and inflammation recovery after eccentric exercise.
results_summary: Quercetin supplementation led to a more marked increase in IGF-I and earlier IGF-II peak compared to placebo, reduced plasma markers of cell damage (CK, LDH, Mb), and lowered interleukin 6 levels during recovery.
population_specificity: Twelve young men
